To find the diagonal matrix D and the invertible matrix P, we first need to find the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of matrix A.

Matrix A:
\begin{bmatrix}
    1 & -2 \\
    -6 & 7 
\end{bmatrix}

The characteristic equation of A is given by the determinant of (A - λI), where λ is the eigenvalue and I is the identity matrix.

det(A - λI) = det(\begin{bmatrix}
    1-λ & -2 \\
    -6 & 7-λ 
\end{bmatrix})

= (1-λ)(7-λ) - (-2)(-6)
= λ^2 - 8λ + 7 + 12
= λ^2 - 8λ + 19

Now, we find the eigenvalues by solving the quadratic equation:

λ^2 - 8λ + 19 = 0

Using the quadratic formula, we get:

λ = (8 ± √(8^2 - 4(19))) / 2
λ = (8 ± √(64 - 76)) / 2
λ = (8 ± √(-12)) / 2
λ = 4 ± i√12

So, the eigenvalues are λ₁ = 4 + i√12 and λ₂ = 4 - i√12.

Now, we find the eigenvectors for each eigenvalue.

For λ₁ = 4 + i√12:

(A - λ₁I)v₁ = 0

\begin{bmatrix}
    1-(4+i√12) & -2 \\
    -6 & 7-(4+i√12) 
\end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix}
    x₁ \\
    x₂
\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}
    0 \\
    0
\end{bmatrix}

\begin{bmatrix}
    -3-i√12 & -2 \\
    -6 & 3-i√12 
\end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix}
    x₁ \\
    x₂
\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}
    0 \\
    0
\end{bmatrix}

From the first row, we have:

(-3-i√12)x₁ - 2x₂ = 0

Let x₂ = 1, then:

x₁ = (2/(-3-i√12))
x₁ = 2(3+i√12)/((3+i√12)(3-i√12))
x₁ = 2(3+i√12)/(9+12)
x₁ = (3+i√12)/7

So, the eigenvector v₁ is:

v₁ = \begin{bmatrix}
    (3+i√12)/7 \\
    1
\end{bmatrix}

For λ₂ = 4 - i√12:

(A - λ₂I)v₂ = 0

\begin{bmatrix}
    1-(4-i√12) & -2 \\
    -6 & 7-(4-i√12) 
\end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix}
    x₁ \\
    x₂
\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}
    0 \\
    0
\end{bmatrix}

\begin{bmatrix}
    -3+i√12 & -2 \\
    -6 & 3+i√12 
\end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix}
    x₁ \\
    x₂
\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}
    0 \\
    0
\end{bmatrix}

From the first row, we have:

(-3+i√12)x₁ - 2x₂ = 0

Let x₂ = 1, then:

x₁ = (2/(-3+i√12))
x₁ = 2(3-i√12)/((3-i√12)(3+i√12))
x₁ = 2(3-i√12)/(9+12)
x₁ = (3-i√12)/7

So, the eigenvector v₂ is:

v₂ = \begin{bmatrix}
    (3-i√12)/7 \\
    1
\end{bmatrix}

Now, we have the eigenvalues and eigenvectors. We can form the matrix P using the eigenvectors as columns:

P = \begin{bmatrix}
    (3+i√12)/7 & (3-i√12)/7 \\
    1 & 1
\end{bmatrix}

The diagonal matrix D will have the eigenvalues on its diagonal:

D = \begin{bmatrix}
    4 + i√12 & 0 \\
    0 & 4 - i√12
\end{bmatrix}

Now, we need to find the inverse of matrix P, denoted as P^(-1). 

P^(-1) = (1/det(P)) * adj(P)

det(P) = ((3+i√12)/7)(1) - ((3-i√12)/7)(1)
det(P) = (3+i√12)/7 - (3-i√12)/7
det(P) = (2i√12)/7

adj(P) = \begin{bmatrix}
    1 & -(3-i√12)/7 \\
    -1 & (3+i√12)/7
\end{bmatrix}

P^(-1) = (1/((2i√12)/7)) * \begin{bmatrix}
    1 & -(3-i√12)/7 \\
    -1 & (3+i√12)/7
\end{bmatrix}

P^(-1) = (7/(2i√12)) * \begin{bmatrix}
    1 & -(3-i√12)/7 \\
    -1 & (3+i√12)/7
\end{bmatrix}

P^(-1) = \begin{bmatrix}
    (7/(2i√12)) & -(7(3-i√12))/(2i√12*7) \\
    -(7/(2i√12)) & (7(3+i√12))/(2i√12*7)
\end{bmatrix}

P^(-1) = \begin{bmatrix}
    (7/(2i√12)) & -(3-i√12)/(2i√12) \\
    -(7/(2i√12)) & (3+i√12)/(2i√12)
\end{bmatrix}

Now, we have the diagonal matrix D and the invertible matrix P and its inverse P^(-1):

A = PDP^(-1) = \begin{bmatrix}
    (3+i√12)/7 & (3-i√12)/7 \\
    1 & 1
\end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix}
    4 + i√12 & 0 \\
    0 & 4 - i√12
\end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix}
    (7/(2i√12)) & -(3-i√12)/(2i√12) \\
    -(7/(2i√12)) & (3+i√12)/(2i√12)
\end{bmatrix}
